results.title: Step right up!
results.creator_credit: Film Communications, Ray Jewell and Mike Lloyd Ross
results.brief_description: Illustrates the possible hazards and improper procedures when using ladders. Shows the proper use of stepladders, straight ladders, and extension ladders. Also focuses on inspection, maintenance, carrying, ladder stances, erecting and securing, climbing and descending. Camera: Peter Good.

results.title: Step family
results.creator_credit: Gordon-Kerckhoff Productions, Centron and Ronald Floethe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Family Life Transitions in Marriage”.
The third in a series of transitions in family life, this episode looks at the adjustments necessary to integrating new family members and the effect that this has on the separated parent.

results.title: Step by step
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Frank Bagnall and Antonio Colacino
results.brief_description: Aid given to cerebral palsied children. Private individuals seeing the need established Spastic centres. Basic school syllabuses are slightly modified to suit the physical and mental ability of each child. Special equipment compensates for handicaps. Difficulty in mixing with others can be overcome with specialised aid in the play centres. Teaching them to walk, balance and control movements, and teaching the deaf to speak require highly specialised therapy.

results.title: Step by step
results.creator_credit: Hubley Studios, Pyramid Films and Faith Hubley
results.brief_description: Created in honour of the International Year of the Child, film director Faith Hubley interprets the world of childhood - as it was, as it is now, and as it might be. Distinctive animated children of every race and nationality appear on the screen, accompanied by the voices of children chanting in Spanish and French, with key phrases spoken in English. Viewers see the bleakness of childhood throughout history, the full range of childhood experiences - from poverty to plenty, work to leisure, and the possibilities of the future when the basic rights of children are recognised by us all. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Step-By-Step Guide to Form S
results.brief_description: This video has been designed to help you work through your Tax Return step by step. Each question on Form S is explained in plain language and, where appropriate, examples are given. Numbers on the screen tell you which question on the form you are working on.

results.title: Stencilling
results.creator_credit: Discovery Video, Sheridan Stumm and John Dobis
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tonia Todman’s craft room”.
Stencilling, a craft that started thousands of years ago with primitive cave painting has become increasingly popular in recent years. It is a very adaptable and creative way for the home decorator to personalise his or her home in a way that is appealing and inexpensive. Tonia Todman tells you all you need to know to be able to enhance your home with charming stencilled designs. Stencils can be applied to your walls, floors, tables, cupboards, beds, boxes, trays, fabrics, the list goes on. Their application can stretch as far as your imagination takes you, to give your home and homeware a unique, picturesque and individual touch. Tonia tells you how to plan and design a stencil, how to transfer designs, how to position and space your stencils for the most effective results, and describes painting techniques and the choice of colour schemes.

results.title: Stencil colouring
results.brief_description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. Pathé Frères developed a stencil technqiue for colouring films that brought Casanova’s costumes alive and colour to his lovers’ cheeks.

constellations_primary.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_primary.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

results.description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. While Technicolor was decades away, the French production company Pathé Frères had developed a technique of stencil-colouring films around 1908. This process used a template for each colour – usually between three and six – and applied it frame by frame. Pathé continued innovating, developing mechanical devices to make the process faster and easier for the more than 400 women colourists working at the company. Thanks to Pathé’s stencil method, Casanova’s costumes shimmered in pink, orange and yellow, and rosy blushes graced his lovers’ cheeks.
description_for_label: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. While Technicolor was decades away, the French production company Pathé Frères had developed a technique of stencil-colouring films around 1908. This process used a template for each colour – usually between three and six – and applied it frame by frame. Pathé continued innovating, developing mechanical devices to make the process faster and easier for the more than 400 women colourists working at the company. Thanks to Pathé’s stencil method, Casanova’s costumes shimmered in pink, orange and yellow, and rosy blushes graced his lovers’ cheeks.
